bibl.title: Junichi Yamamoto v. Luther Weedin. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION
PETITION
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF JUNICHI, YAMAMOTO, FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS.
TO THE JUDGES OF THE ABOVE ENTITLED COURT:
Comes now Junichi Yamamoto and respectfully petitions the above entitled court and represents as follows:
I
That your petitioner is a citizen of the Empire of Japan and since September 17, 1917 has been a resident of the Western District of the State of Washington.
II

That your petitioner was born December 22, 1890 in Japan and at all times resided in Japan until on or about the first day of September, 1917 when your petitioner shipped as an able bodied seaman on the steamship "Taiyo Maru", a Japanese vessel registered under the laws of Japan, and came by a direct passage of said steamship from the Empire of Japan to Seattle, Washington, without touching at any other country besides the United States. That your petitioner in order to leave Japan and reach the United States was not required by any of the official authorities of either the United States or Japan to have a passport of any kind or description whatsoever, but your petitioner came as a member of the crew of said steamship, and your petitioner's name was carried upon the crew list of said steamship, which was vised by the American Consul at the point

OF departure of said vessel in Japan. That at the time of the arrival of said ship in a direct route from the Empire of Japan to Seattle, Washington, your petitioner deserted said ship and ever since September 17, 1917 has been and is now a resident of Seattle, Washington.
III

That Luther Weedin, United States Commissioner of Immigration, located at Seattle, Washington, on the 10th day of January, 1922, received by telegram from the United States Department of Labor, a warrant for the arrest of your petitioner, which warrant was in words and figures as follows, to-wit:

"Arrest following named alien and grant hearing, forwarding record of proceed- ings to Department: Jutichi Yamamoto. Entered in Violation of Rule 11 of the Immigration Rules. Likely to become a public charge at time of entry."
IV

That after said arrest your petitioner was given a hearing before Arthur J. Kahl, an Immigrant Inspector at the United States Immigration Office at Seattle, Washington. That said hearing was held on the 10th day of January, 1922 and thereafter continued to January 16th, 1922. That at said hearing testimony was taken and a complete transcript of all proceedings that occurred at said hearing is attached hereto and marked Exhibit "A". That thereafter a transcript of said proceedings before said Immigrant Inspector, an exact copy of Exhibit "A" hereto attached, was sent by Luther Weedin, United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, to the United States Department of Labor at Washington, D.C., and upon the record as contained in Exhibit "A" and solely upon said record, the Assistant Secretary of Labor at Washington, D.C. issued a warrant directing the deportation of petitioner
to Japan.
V

That thereafter Luther Weedin, United States Commission- er of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, notified your peti- tioner, Junichi Yamamoto, to surrender himself into custody at the United States Immigration Station at Seattle, Washington, and your petitioner has, pursuant to said order surrendered himself to said United States Immigration Commissioner and is now in the custody of said commissioner and under arrest by said commissioner, pursuant to said warrant for deporatation issued by the said Assistant Secretary of Labor at Washington, D.C.
VI

That at no time prior hereto has this petitioner been a person likely to become a public charge. That at the time your petitioner landed at Seattle, Washington, on September 17, 1917, your petitioner had in his possession eight hundred Japanese gold yen, equivalent at that time to approximately Four hundred Dollars in United States gold coin. That since said time your petitioner has been engaged in farming, has paid $800.00 upon a Ford truck and has sent to his home in Japan the sum of Fifteen Hundred Dollars. That your petitioner recently sold his equity in said truck for the sum of Four hundred and fifty Dollars. That your petitioner is healthy, able-bodied and well able to earn his own living.
VII
That your petitioner is being unlawfully deprived of his liberty in violation of Article V of amendments to the Constitution of the United States. That your petitioner is being deprived of

his liberty without due process of law, in this: that under the statutes of the United States in such cases made and pro- vided, your petitioner cannot be deported from the United States after the expiration of three years from the date when your petitioner landed at Seattle, Washington; and in this: that your petitioner has never at any time been brought before a special board of inquiry for examination as to your petition- er's qualification for admission into the United States. That your petitioner is being deprived of his liberty without due process of law, in this: That your petitioner has never at any time held a passport to proceed to any country other than the continental territoy of the United States, but came to Seattle, Washington, without any passport whatsoever, while acting as an able-bodied seaman upon a Japanese vessel. That your petitioner left the Empire of Japan on a direct passage to Seattle, Washington, without being required to have any passport of any kind whatsoever, and your petitioner during said passage did not touch at any country other than the con- tinental territory of the United States. That your petitioner does not come within any of the classes excluded by the Immigration Laws of the United States; that your petitioner did not enter and is not in the United States in violation of any law of the United States.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner prays that this court may issue a writ of habeas corpus directing Luther Weedin, United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, to have the body of your petitioner before this Honorable Court at a day to be fixed by said court, and that upon said day your

petitioner be discharged from the custody of said United States Commissioner of Immigration, and be allowed to go hence; that this court adjudge your petitioner is being held without war- rant of law and without due process of law, in violation of Article V of the Constitution of the United States; that pending the hearing upon said writ of habeas corpus, that this court admit your petitioner to bail on furnishing a bond in such penal sum as to the court shall seem proper, and for such other and further relief as to the court shall seem just and equitable.
Junichi Yamamoto
Petitioner
Gates & Helsell
Attorneys for Petitioner
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA STATE OF WASHINGTON
COUNTY OF KING
ss.

JUNICHI YAMAMOTO, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is the petitioner above named; that he has read the foregoing petition, knows the contents thereof and that the same are true as he verily belies.
Junichi Yamamoto
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 9th day of March, 1922.
Frank P. Helsell
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington residing at Seattle.
